bioghist.p: John Muirhead Macfarlane (1855-1943) was a Scottish botanist. He held several different academic positions at the University of Edinburgh before emigrating to the United States in 1893, where he became a professor of botany at the University of Pennsylvania. He held this position until his retirement in 1920. He also served as the director of Penn's Botanic Garden and played a leading role in organizing and diversifying it. Macfarlane is most well known for his first book, The Causes and Course of Organic Evolution; A Study in Bioenergics (1918). He also wrote many other works including The Evolution and Distribution of Flowering Plants, The Evolution and Distribution of Fishes and The Quantity and Sources of Our Petroleum Supplies.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of manuscripts for several publications by Macfarlane. Titles include: Fishes the Source of Petroleum, 1922 (typescript); A Report from the Spec. American Petroleum Institute, 1925; The Evolution and Distribution of Asclepiadaceae; "The Fishes of the Ancient Mediterranean Basin in Relation to Supplies of Petroleum," 1923 (manuscript); and Quantity and Sources of Our Petroleum Supplies, 1929 (typescript).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
